museum.schoolHistory: History of the school in the history of the city
museum.schoolAddressOne: State educational institutions Secondary school No. 8 Mogilev Minsky lane 4, room 307,
museum.schoolAddressTwo: historical and local history profile, basic direction – history of our school
museum.workMuseumOffice: Work of the school museum office
museum.workMuseumOfficeDescriptions: Accumulation of material and exhibits, accounting and storage of museum collections
museum.culturalActivitiesDescriptions: On the basis of the museum there is an association of interests “Young Guides”
museum.schoolAccessoriesDescription: Textbooks, ink pens, inkwell, notebooks, diaries of students of school No. 8 of different years, educational certificates and matriculation certificates, children's newspapers and magazines from the 70s-80s, school textbooks from the 50s-80s, school photographs, starting from 1941, Soviet-style school and pioneer uniforms, school backpack, badges of October activists, pioneers, Komsomol members, pioneer ties, Komsomol tickets school graduates
museum.photoArchiveDescription: The photo archive is made up not only of school photographs, but there are also photographs of all the directors and head teachers of the school, outstanding graduates, among whom are internationalist soldiers, athletes, an artist, a professor, the director of the regional museum of local history and a veteran of Baikanur, teachers, and many others
museum.periodicalsDescription: The museum hall displays a selection of periodicals in which articles about our school were published. Exhibits from the period of the Great Patriotic War, ausweiss from 1943, issued by the commandant's office of Mogilev (transferred from the family archive in 2016), medical instruments and a gramophone from 1959, families of a school graduate from 1956
museum.fateSchool: The fate of the school, its teachers and graduates during the Great Patriotic War
museum.teacherWork: About the work of our school teachers
museum.graduates: About the outstanding graduates of our school
museum.pioneer: History of the pioneer and Komsomol organization
museum.schoolUniform: History of school uniforms and school supplies

schoolMuseum.firstSocialistSchool: The first socialist school in the city of Mogilev, which received serial number 23, accepted students from 1st to 8th grade (September 1939)
schoolMuseum.firstSocialistSchoolMogilev: Once upon a time, on the site where our school is located, there was a rustling birch grove. But in 1939 a building was erected here the first socialist school in the city of Mogilev, which received the serial number 23. This is how the story begins our school. The school was built in the village of Chapaevka, which was only included in the city in the 30s it was included in the city limits
schoolMuseum.oneDirectorDescription: The first director of the new school was Minin Zakhar Matveevich, he left this position because he went to Finnish war. The fate of Z.M. Minin decreed that he became a participant first in the Finnish War, and then in the Great Patriotic, after which he returned to Mogilev, but did not appear within the walls of our school until 1989 of the year
schoolMuseum.twoDirectorDescription: In 1940, the second director was Pavel Kirillovich Kazimirsky, who headed secondary school No. 23 until the tragic 1941 of the year. At the beginning of the Great Patriotic War, P.K. Kazimirsky, fulfilling a special task of the NKVD, disappeared without lead
schoolMuseum.directorOlenskyDescription: After the liberation of Mogilev, the city administration began preparing the school for the school year. As a result of the reform, it received serial number 8 instead of 23. Pyotr Lvovich Olensky (1944-1957), a participant in the partisan movement, was appointed director. In 1947, the first graduation of 10th graders from secondary school No. 8 took place. Kuleshova Anastasia Mikhailovna, Honored Teacher of the Republic of Belarus among students (1949).
schoolMuseum.yearDescription: At the school there was a Komsomol organization, a pioneer squad and units of October soldiers. A photograph of members of the Komsomol cell of Secondary School No. 23 (now 8) in 1941 has been preserved. The photo shows 6 people. After the end of the war, only two remained alive... The students sought to get an education and find their place in this life, but the war cruelly interfered with their plans. Graduates of our school, like all Soviet citizens, entered the fight against Nazi Germany.
schoolMuseum.yearDescriptionDefenseMogilev: Defense of Mogilev, one of the lines of which took place in the area of the Shklovskoe highway, where a police battalion under the command of Captain Vladimirov heroically fought near the village of Gai. Unfortunately, Soviet soldiers were forced to retreat and the fighting continued on the streets of the city. Pechkurova V.P., a resident of our area, recalls that the militia and the surviving policemen of the police battalion occupied the building of our school and held its defense for seven days. The Germans were able to capture the school only when the last soldier who defended it died. The entire school yard was littered with spent cartridges. The number of dead on both sides was so great that the Germans had to ask the local population to take the corpses to neighboring villages and bury them there. Initially, a detachment of policemen was stationed here, who in a short time turned the school building and the surrounding area into a landfill.
schoolMuseum.1942: At the beginning of 1942, the policemen dormitory was moved to another location, and the vacant building was given over to the German railway commandant's office: a stable was built on the first floor, and the commandant's office itself was located on the second floor, a small part of which was isolated by an armored door. The school building was painted in a khaki color. According to the memoirs of V.P. Pechkurova, not a single bomb during the bombing of Mogilev by Soviet pilots hit either the building of our school, or the building of 24 and the railway, modern evening schools. The fact is that among the pilots there were graduates of these schools who wanted to preserve the integrity of the buildings so that after liberation the children would have a place to study.
schoolMuseum.pty: With the help of students of vocational school-58, labor teachers and students of school No. 8, a second one-story building was built, which housed
schoolMuseum.ptyTwo: labor workshops, extended day group, chemistry room, gym.
schoolMuseum.ptyThree: War veterans also continued to work at the school: Andrei Markovich Korotkiy, Roman Semenovich Khalchukov
schoolMuseum.demolishedBuilding: The second building was demolished and the foundation of a new school building was laid. Almost no work was done for about 10 years.
schoolMuseum.demolishedBuildingTwo: Teachers and students have repeatedly protested for the continuation of construction
schoolMuseum.symbolicKey: On September 1, director Valery Mikhailovich Klepchukov received a symbolic key and students crossed the threshold of the new school
schoolMuseum.schoolBlown: On August 20, the old school building was blown up because it was in disrepair and could not be repaired.
schoolMuseum.schoolBlownTwo: From May 20 to June 13, 2023, the director was Alexander Ivanovich Korzun
schoolMuseum.directorIrinaLeonidovnaRybakova: On June 14, Irina Leonidovna Rybakova was appointed director of the secondary school.

historyUniforms.eventsForms: is a mandatory everyday form of clothing for students during their stay at school and at official school events outside of school
historyUniforms.1918: In 1918, the gymnasium uniform of pre-revolutionary Russia was recognized as a bourgeois relic and abolished along with many other reasonable developments in the field of education
historyUniforms.classStruggle: From the point of view of the «class struggle», the old form was considered a symbol of belonging to the upper classes (there was even a contemptuous nickname for a sentimental girl — «high school girl»)
historyUniforms.studentLackFreedom: On the other hand, the form symbolized the absolute lack of freedom of the student, his humiliated and servile position
historyUniforms.background: But this rejection of the form had another, more understandable, background
historyUniforms.provideParents: Students went to school in what their parents could provide them, and at that moment the state was actively fighting against devastation, class enemies and remnants of the past
historyUniforms.experiments: However, over time, when the era of experimentation gave way to other realities, it was decided to return to the
historyUniforms.strict: to brown formal dresses, aprons, student jackets and turn-down collars
historyUniforms.bourgeoisLicentiousness: began to be associated with bourgeois unbridleness, and it was decided to declare all the daring experimenters of the 1920s «pests» and
historyUniforms.ussrForms: In the USSR, the school uniform was changed several times. There were several models. The girls had a classic brown dress with a black (casual) or white (for special events) apron tied at the back with a bow
historyUniforms.cuffs: were modestly decorated with lace collars and cuffs
historyUniforms.compulsory: Wearing a collar and cuffs was mandatory. In addition, girls could wear black or brown (casual) or white (formal)
historyUniforms.wereNotAllowed: of other colors were not allowed according to the rules. In general, the uniform for girls was not much different from the pre-revolutionary model
historyUniforms.spread: The strictness of the mores of the Stalin era extended, of course, to school life
historyUniforms.administration: The most minor experiments with the length or other parameters of the school uniform were severely punished by the administration of the educational institution
historyUniforms.hairstyle: Even the hairstyle had to meet the requirements of Puritanical morality — «model haircuts» were strictly prohibited until the end of the 50s, not to mention hair coloring. Girls always wore braids with bows
historyUniforms.movies: of the era can be seen in the films «First Grader», «Alyosha Ptitsyn develops character» and «Vasek Trubachev and his comrades»
historyUniforms.affected: of the regime did not immediately affect the democratization of school uniforms, however, it still happened
historyUniforms.shapeCut: The cut of the uniform has become more identical to the fashion trends that took place in the
historyUniforms.luckyMans: However, only the boys were lucky. Since the mid-
historyUniforms.grayTrousers: gray wool trousers and jackets have been replaced by trousers and jackets made of blue woolen fabric. The cut of the jackets resembled classic denim jackets (the so-called «denim fashion» was gaining momentum in the world)
historyUniforms.sleeves: On the side of the sleeve was sewn an
historyUniforms.plastic: made of soft plastic with an open textbook and a rising sun painted on it
historyUniforms.schoolchildrenEnd: We can see schoolchildren of the late
historyUniforms.cultFilm: in the cult film «Let's Live to Monday»
historyUniforms.introduced: In the early 1980s, a uniform for
historyUniforms.eighth: (This uniform began to be worn from the eighth grade)
historyUniforms.fromFirstToSeventhGrade: from the first to the seventh grade wore a brown dress, as in the previous period. Only it was not much higher than the knees
historyUniforms.costume: trousers and a jacket were replaced with a pantsuit. The color of the fabric was still blue. The
historyUniforms.onTheSleeve: on the sleeve was also blue
historyUniforms.cutOff: was cut off, as it did not look too aesthetically pleasing, especially after some time — the paint on the plastic began to wear off
historyUniforms.canSee: can be seen, for example, in the films  «Guest from the Future» and «Adventures of Electronics»
historyUniforms.threePieceSuit: In 1984, a three-piece blue suit was introduced, consisting of a trapeze skirt with pleats in the front, a jacket with patch pockets and a vest. The skirt could be worn either with a jacket, or with a vest, or the whole suit at once
historyUniforms.leningrad: In 1988, Leningrad, Siberia and the Far North were allowed to wear blue trousers in winter
historyUniforms.wasDifferent: In some Soviet republics, the style of school uniforms was slightly different, as well as the color.
historyUniforms.ukraine: So, in Ukraine, the school uniform was brown, although blue was not prohibited either
historyUniforms.contributed: that contributed to the fact that they began to realize their attractiveness early
historyUniforms.pleated: A pleated skirt, a vest and, most importantly, blouses that could be experimented with turned almost any schoolgirl into a
historyUniforms.mandatoryAddition: An obligatory addition to the school uniform, depending on the age of the student, were the
historyUniforms.pioneer: (in elementary grades), pioneer (in middle grades) or Komsomol (in high school)
historyUniforms.mustWear: Pioneers were also required to wear a
historyUniforms.pioneerBadge: In addition to the usual pioneer badge, there was a special option for
historyUniforms.bitMore: It was slightly larger than usual and had the inscription
historyUniforms.thereNoSingle: there is no uniform school uniform, as it was in the
historyUniforms.ownForm: but many lyceums and gymnasiums, especially the most prestigious ones, have their own uniforms, emphasizing the belonging of students to a particular educational institution
historyUniforms.bigEuropeanCountry: The largest European country in which
historyUniforms.formerColonies: In many of its former colonies, the uniform was not abolished even after independence, for example in India, Ireland, Austria, Singapore and South Africa
historyUniforms.noUniformUniform: There is no uniform uniform, although there is a debate about its introduction
historyUniforms.studentsCanDevelopment: clothes have been introduced, which is not a uniform, since students can participate in its development
historyUniforms.duringThirdReich: Tellingly, even during the Third Reich, schoolchildren did not have a uniform uniform — they came to classes in casual clothes, in the form of the Hitler Youth (or other children's public organizations)
historyUniforms.privateSchools: there are school uniforms in many private schools
historyUniforms.publicSchools: There is no uniform uniform in public schools, although some schools have introduced dress code rules. In Cuba, the uniform is mandatory for all students of schools and higher educational institutions
historyUniforms.mostAverage: In Cuba, uniforms are mandatory for all students of schools and higher educational institutions in
historyUniforms.options: School uniforms are considered mandatory. Each school has its own, but in fact there are not so many options. Usually it is a white shirt and a dark jacket and trousers for
historyUniforms.whiteShirt: and a white shirt and a dark jacket and skirt for
historyUniforms.sailorSuit: or sailor fuku - «sailor suit». A large bag or briefcase is usually given to the form
historyUniforms.rule: as a rule, dress in ordinary children's clothes
